name: chicagotribune
text:
A video shows Chicago police giving a CTA supervisor a choice: Drop a complaint against an officer or face arrest. 

“Is it worth it to you?” a sergeant asked. 

It was. Minutes later, she was in handcuffs. https://t.co/EKSdWSjohm

name: chicagotribune
text: A group of aldermen plan to file an ordinance that would seek to remove Chicago police officers from the city's public schools. https://t.co/SZoBCYygEW

name: chicagotribune
text: The University of Illinois at Chicago will begin testing a potential vaccine for COVID-19 next month, with expectations of enrolling at least 1,000 local participants in the clinical trial. https://t.co/9Ybbn43RxP

name: chicagotribune
text: Can you get fired for protesting? Or spouting off on social media? It depends, so here's what you should know. https://t.co/TMpvmWEP66

name: chicagotribune
text: The Illinois Republican Party is suing Gov. Pritzker in federal court, seeking an exemption from the 10-person limit on public gatherings. https://t.co/fQVvApG3jI

name: chicagotribune
text: Commentary: Our city’s most precious resource is our youth. Chicago’s future rests on their dreams, and they need us to help them own it, Mayor Lori Lightfoot and Amy Eshleman write. https://t.co/8t4C3iaDuw

name: chicagotribune
text: A Chicago police officer was shot in the knee Monday night on the South Side. https://t.co/vmCohhiCDx

text: Column: Baseball is edging closer to another disaster — will history repeat itself? https://t.co/ffUeKPRclM

text: President Trump is trying to break apart a fragile multiracial alliance, writes columnist @dahleeng. https://t.co/OZeXpWe0nc

name: chicagotribune
text: A 54-year-old man riding a bike died early Tuesday after he was the unintended target in a Rogers Park shooting, according to Chicago police. https://t.co/PvWCKKiCFG

name: chicagotribune
text: Chicago's Lakefront Trail will reopen solely for exercise and transit from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. starting on June 22, but residents must “keep it moving,” the mayor's office said. https://t.co/lKfyPg3X8J

name: chicagotribune
text: The Illinois Republican Party, along with three local GOP groups, sued Gov. J.B. Pritzker on Monday, arguing his limit on in-person gatherings unfairly curtails people’s First Amendment rights. https://t.co/Z9cmkhYmSC

name: chicagotribune
text: Six former eBay employees are accused of trying to terrorize the editor and publisher of an online newsletter by sending live spiders and roaches, a funeral wreath and other alarming items to their home, prosecutors said. https://t.co/9JvuItB3hL

name: chicagotribune
text:
Good morning, Chicago. Here are some top stories to start your day:
-Lakefront Trail set to reopen as city takes steps forward
-How one Chicago school reeled in 2,800 students amid COVID-19
-Can you get fired for protesting? It depends.
https://t.co/QVznUg30oJ

name: chicagotribune
text: Critics contend a video showing Chicago police arresting a CTA supervisor after urging her to dismiss her complaint against an officer highlights a decades-old “code of silence” — an unwritten understanding that officers protect one another at all cost. https://t.co/fPguPcbUcl

name: chicagotribune
text: The Rockefeller Foundation's new initiative will invest $10 million in 10 U.S. cities, including Chicago, to promote economic equity for low-wage workers and minority-owned small businesses. https://t.co/jZFBtiYdm7

text: An 18-year-old man was arrested Sunday in connection to a fatal shooting in Marquette Park in May https://t.co/DAbvdyLr95

text: 11 Chicagoans each awarded $50,000 by Field Foundation for the plans they have to make a difference in the city. More on them and their projects here. https://t.co/TB7gOzvy5V

text: Coronavirus in Illinois updates: State reports lowest daily deaths from COVID-19 in months as UIC says it will begin testing a vaccine https://t.co/sIodcmvgZG

text: Pandemic High: How one of Chicago's largest high schools used technology and personal touch to reach students remotely, via @MilaKoumpilova of @ChalkbeatCHI https://t.co/EmDyu1qvwU

text: Two dead in shooting at Munster, Ind., hospital, police say https://t.co/9P5ZkYnuq4

text: Researchers in England say they have the first evidence that a drug can improve COVID-19 survival: A cheap, widely available steroid called dexamethasone reduced deaths by up to one third in severely ill hospitalized patients https://t.co/xWkpdO5uCD

text: Shake Shack workers did not purposely sicken three cops with bleach in their milkshakes, the New York Police Department has determined: “no criminality” https://t.co/PpqmULsMag

name: chicagotribune
text:
"An extremely welcome result"

First evidence that a drug can improve COVID-19 survival: A cheap, widely available steroid called dexamethasone reduced deaths by up to one third in severely ill hospitalized patients, study finds. https://t.co/nN2pFzXB5N
